message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="STV: Foreword and/or Translator's Preface">
NEW VOTE (replaces previous): Front matter structure for the English edition.

The author may write a Preface later — that's separate. For now, we're deciding about the Foreword and Translator's Preface.

Three options:
A. **Foreword only** (written by an outside scholar/figure)
B. **Foreword + Translator's Preface** (both)
C. **Translator's Preface only** (no foreword)

SINGLE TRANSFERABLE VOTE. Rank all three:

"1st: [A/B/C] — 2nd: [A/B/C] — 3rd: [A/B/C] — Reason: [brief justification]"
</teammate-message>

input.content: 1st: C — 2nd: B — 3rd: A — Reason: The Translator's Preface is the non-negotiable piece. It must carry the terminological apparatus (境-family system, the 形/现象 reinterpretation, 德 as "character" not "virtue"), the structural guidance (fish/fishing metaphor, prescribed reading order), and the critical warning that experiential sequences are philosophical experiments — all of which my Analysis Report (Section 6b) shows are essential for the essays to function on English-language readers. A Foreword by an outside scholar is a nice-to-have for legitimation and framing, but it risks two problems: (1) it may impose an interpretive lens before the reader encounters the work (the author's whole point is that meaning is generated from within, not imposed from without), and (2) finding the right scholar for a work that spans physics, category theory, Chinese philosophy, and post-nihilist existentialism is non-trivial — a poor match would do more harm than good. If an ideal foreword writer exists (someone genuinely engaged with the work, not just lending a name), option B becomes attractive, but C alone is sufficient and safe.
input.summary: STV: 1st C, 2nd B, 3rd A — Translator's Preface essential

routing.summary: STV: 1st C, 2nd B, 3rd A — Translator's Preface essential

A Foreword by an outside scholar is a nice-to-have for legitimation and framing, but it risks two problems: (1) it may impose an interpretive lens before the reader encounters the work (the author's whole point is that meaning is generated from within, not imposed from without), and (2) finding the right scholar for a work that spans physics, category theory, Chinese philosophy, and post-nihilist existentialism is non-trivial — a poor match would do more harm than good. If an ideal foreword writer exists (someone genuinely engaged with the work, not just lending a name), option B becomes attractive, but C alone is sufficient and safe.

content.text: Waiting for the next instruction from the team lead.
